en: Thus, Khamenei said, all previous peace agreements -- such as the 1993 Oslo Accords, the two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and former U.S. President Donald Trump's plan dubbed the Deal of the Century "are null and void".
ny: Choncho, Khamenei anati mapangano onse a mtendere akale - monga mapangano a ku Oslo a 1993, njira ya mayiko aŵiri yothetsera nkhondo ya Israeli ndi Palestina, ndi mapulani a pulezidenti wakale wa United States, Donald Trump omwe anawatcha kuti Pangano la Zaka Zoyamba "alibe kanthu".

en: President Ebrahim Raisi, Irans military commanders and senior officials also attended the rallies in which people were allowed to march through the streets, the first time since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic two years ago.
ny: Purezidenti Ebrahim Raisi, akuluakulu a asilikali a Iran ndi akuluakulu ena anapezekanso pamisonkhano yomwe anthu analoledwa kuyenda m'misewu, kwa nthawi yoyamba kuyambira pomwe mliri wa coronavirus udayambika zaka ziwiri zapitazo.

en: Iran's Jerusalem Day rallies are held annually in support of Palestinians, who want East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state in territories captured by Israel in a 1967 war, on the last Friday of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.
ny: Misonkhano ya tsiku la Yerusalemu ku Iran imachitika chaka chilichonse pothandiza Apalestina, omwe akufuna kuti Yerusalemu Wachilimwe akhale likulu la boma lamtsogolo m'malo omwe Israeli adagwira pankhondo ya 1967, Lachisanu lomaliza la mwezi wa Ramadan.

en: "Stop your vicious deeds. You know well that we are people of action and reaction," Revolutionary Guards commander Hossein Salami, addressing Israel, told demonstrators in Tehran.
ny: "Lekani kuchita zoipa, mukudziwa bwino kuti ndife anthu ochita zinthu ndi kuchitapo kanthu", mtsogoleri wa asilikali a asilikali oteteza zachitetezo cha dziko la Israel, Hossein Salami, anauza anthu omwe ankachita zionetsero ku Tehran.

en: "Our responses are painful. You create conditions for your own destruction. We will not leave you alone ...You know better than me what will befall you if you take evil action."
ny: "Zimene tikuyankhazo ndi zopweteka.Mukufuna kuti muwonongeke nokha.Sitidzakusiyani nokha...Inu mukudziwa bwino kuposa ine zimene zidzachitike ngati mutengapo mbali pa zinthu zoipa".

en: Iran's military has vowed to retaliate harshly against any attack by Israel, which has often voiced concern over the Iranian nuclear program. Tehran says the program is for peaceful purposes only.
ny: Asilikali a Iran alonjeza kuti adzabwezera mwamphamvu pa kuukira kulikonse kwa Israeli, komwe nthawi zambiri kumafotokoza nkhawa zake za pulogalamu ya nyukiliya ya Iran. Tehran imanena kuti pulogalamuyi ndi ya mtendere chabe.

en: Israel, whose existence the Islamic Republic does not recognize, has long threatened military action against Iran if talks between Tehran and world powers fail to curb Iranian nuclear activity. Iran says its nuclear ambitions are peaceful.
ny: Israel, yomwe kulibe kuitanidwa ndi Islamic Republic, yakhala ikuwopseza kuti idzachita zinthu zankhondo motsutsana ndi Iran ngati zokambirana pakati pa Tehran ndi mayiko apadziko lonse sizingaletse ntchito za nyukiliya za Iran.

en: In February, the Islamic Republic unveiled its "Kheibar Buster" missile with a range of 1,450 km (900 miles).
ny: Mu February, dziko la Islamic Republic linatulutsa mfuti yake ya "Kheibar Buster" yokhala ndi mtunda wa makilomita 1,450 (mailo 900).

en: Iran, which has one of the biggest missile programs in the Middle East, says its ballistic missiles have a range of up to 2,000 km (1,200 miles) and are capable of reaching its arch-foe Israel and U.S. bases in the region.
ny: Dziko la Iran, lomwe lili ndi imodzi mwa mapulogalamu akuluakulu a mfuti ku Middle East, limati mfuti zake za balistikasi zili ndi mtunda wa makilomita 2,000 ndipo zimatha kufika pa Israeli ndi US omwe ndi adani ake aakulu m'derali.

en: Kheibar refers to an ancient Jewish oasis in the Arabian Peninsula's Hijaz region that was overrun by Muslim warriors in the 7th century.
ny: Kheibar amatanthauza malo akale achiyuda omwe anali m'chigawo cha Hijaz ku Arabia Peninsula omwe anawagonjetsedwa ndi asilikali achisilamu m'zaka za zana la 7.

en: Tehran regards its ballistic missile program as an important deterrent against the United States, Israel and other adversaries, and has rejected Western demands to halt it.
ny: Tehran ikuona kuti pulogalamu yake ya zipolopolo ndi yofunika kwambiri yoletsa United States, Israel ndi adani ena, ndipo yakana zofuna za West kuti ziimitse.

en: Over the past year, Iran and the United States have engaged in fitful, indirect talks in Vienna to revive a 2015 nuclear deal that then-President Donald Trump reneged on in 2018 and that Iran, in turn, began violating in 2019.
ny: Chaka chatha, Iran ndi United States akhala akukambirana mosapita m'mbali ku Vienna kuti abwezeretse mgwirizano wa nyukiliya wa 2015 umene pulezidenti wakale Donald Trump anachoka nawo mu 2018 ndipo Iran inayamba kuwuphwanya mu 2019.

en: Under the 2015 deal, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in return for relief from economic sanctions.
ny: Mogwirizana ndi mgwirizano wa 2015, Iran inavomera kuchepetsa pulogalamu yake ya nyukiliya pofuna kuthetsa mavuto a zachuma.

en: While they appeared close to resurrecting the deal in March, talks stalled over last-minute Russian demands and whether Washington might drop Iran's Revolutionary Guards from its Foreign Terrorist Organization list.
ny: Ngakhale kuti ankaoneka kuti akufuna kubwezeretsa mgwirizanowu mu March, zokambirana zinayima chifukwa cha zimene Russia inafuna ndipo anafunsa ngati Washington angachotse asilikali a Iran pa mndandanda wa bungwe la zigawenga zakunja.

en: As Fewer Americans Attend Church, Can Coffee Shops Fill the Void?
ny: Pamene Anthu a ku America Ochepa Amapita ku Tchalitchi, Kodi Malo Ogulitsa Makafe Angadzaze Malo Opanda Anthu?

en: Churches and other houses of worship have historically played critical social and political functions in American society. But fewer people are attending religious services, and the decline of churches and other houses of worship threatens to leave a void that could potentially be filled by coffee shops.
ny: Tchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zopembedzera zakhala zikugwira ntchito yofunika kwambiri pazochitika za anthu ndi ndale m'boma la America. Koma anthu ochepa akulowa misonkhano yachipembedzo, ndipo kuchepa kwa mipingo ndi nyumba zina zopembedzera kukuwopseza kusiya malo opanda kanthu omwe angadzazidwe ndi malo ogulitsa khofi.

en: "For so much of American history, the church has really been — or their congregations have really been — essential, providing an unheralded role in providing cohesion and connectedness in communities … encouraging civic engagement and political participation," says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
ny: "Kwa nthaŵi yaitali m'mbiri ya America, mpingo wakhaladi wofunika kwambiri, kapena mipingo yawo yakhala yofunika kwambiri, kupereka ntchito yosayembekezereka m'kupereka mgwirizano ndi kugwirizana m'madera... yolimbikitsa anthu kuchita nawo zinthu ndiponso kutenga nawo mbali m'ndale", akutero Daniel Cox, mkulu wa Survey Center on American Life ndi katswiri wamkulu wa American Enterprise Institute.

en: "It was not happenstance or luck that the civil rights movement emerged out of the church," Cox says.
ny: Cox anati: "Sinali mwangozi kapena mwayi kuti gulu la ufulu wa anthu linachokera m'tchalitchi".

en: "And you see that cross-culturally … whether it's in predominantly white rural communities, in the suburbs, wherever, churches have historically been really, really important."
ny: "Ndipo mukuona kuti pakati pa zikhalidwe... kaya zili m'madera akumidzi omwe anthu awo ndi azungu, m'midzi, kulikonse, matchalitchi akhala ofunika kwambiri".

en: Churches and other houses of worship have also played a role in helping immigrants assimilate once they arrive in America, Cox says.
ny: Cox anati matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zopembedzera zathandizanso anthu osamukira ku America kuti akapeze zinthu zofunika akangofika.

en: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they belonged to a church, mosque or synagogue.
ny: Mu 1999, anthu 70 pa anthu 100 alionse a ku America ananena kuti anali m'tchalitchi, mzikiti kapena sunagoge.

en: By 2020, that number had dropped to 47%. A 2019 survey found that only about three in 10 Americans say they attend weekly religious services.
ny: Pofika mu 2020, chiwerengero chimenechi chinachepa kufika pa 47%. Kafukufuku amene anachitika mu 2019 anasonyeza kuti anthu atatu pa anthu 10 alionse a ku America okha ndi amene amanena kuti amapita ku misonkhano ya chipembedzo mlungu uliwonse.

en: Third places  Lack of involvement and affiliation with churches, mosques and synagogues means people might be missing out on what urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg dubbed as "third places" — public gathering spots that offer something that home, the "first place," and work, the "second place," might not.
ny: Malo achitatu Kusakhala ndi mbali ndi kugwirizana ndi matchalitchi, mzikiti ndi masunagoge kumatanthauza kuti anthu akhoza kuphonya zomwe katswiri wa zamagulu a anthu Ray Oldenburg anazitcha kuti "malo achitatu"  malo osonkhanira anthu omwe amapereka chinachake chomwe nyumba, "malo oyamba, "ndi ntchito, "malo achiwiri, "sangakhale.

en: Oldenburg argued that third places are critical to a communitys social vitality.
ny: Oldenburg ananena kuti malo achitatu ndi ofunika kwambiri kuti anthu azikhala ndi moyo wabwino.

en: An October 2021 survey conducted by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces like coffee houses foster trust and connection in American communities and could help fill the void left by churches.
ny: Kafukufuku wochitidwa mu October 2021 ndi American Survey Center adapeza kuti malo ogulitsa monga malo ogulitsira khofi amalimbikitsa kudalira ndi kulumikizana m'magulu aku America ndipo atha kuthandiza kudzaza malo opanda kanthu omwe amatsala ndi matchalitchi.

en: "If you're a regular at a cafe, the barista may know what you usually order, and they can make it for you, and that feels good," says clinical psychologist Dr. Maria Espinola, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
ny: "Ngati mumakonda kupita ku cafe, barista angadziŵe zimene mumakonda kuitanitsa, ndipo angakupangireni, ndipo zimenezi zimakondweretsa", akutero katswiri wa zamaganizo a zachipatala Dr. Maria Espinola, pulofesa wothandizira pa Dipatimenti ya Psychiatry ndi Behavioral Neuroscience ku University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.

en: "It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are expecting you, to know that people care about you, to know that you belong, because the need for belonging and human connection is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important to have that fulfilled in different ways," Espinola says.
ny: Espinola anati: "Zimakhala bwino kudziwika, kudziwa kuti anthu akukuyembekezerani, kudziwa kuti anthu amakuderani nkhawa, kudziwa kuti ndinu munthu wofunika, chifukwa kufunika kwa kukhala ndi anthu ena ndiponso kugwirizana ndi anthu n'kofunika kwambiri kwa tonsefe, ndipo n'kofunika kuti zimenezi zikwaniritsidwe m'njira zosiyanasiyana".

en: "So, places like third places can allow us to do that."
ny: "Kotero malo monga malo achitatu angatipatse mwayi wochita zimenezo".

en: In the past, churches and other houses of worship have been a third place for many Americans.
ny: M'mbuyomu, matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zopembedzera zakhala malo achitatu kwa anthu ambiri a ku America.

en: In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they have a third place — a coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other place in their community that they visit regularly.
ny: Mu 2019, 67% ya anthu omwe anafunsidwa ananena kuti ali ndi malo atatu  khofi, bar, malo odyera, paki kapena malo ena m'dera lawo omwe amawachezera pafupipafupi.

en: That number dropped to 56% in 2021 — a number that could have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
ny: Chiwerengerocho chinatsika kufika pa 56% mu 2021  chiwerengero chomwe chikadakhudzidwa ndi mliri wa COVID-19.

en: "What we found was that people who had a third place were much more connected to their community," says Cox. "They're much more likely to engage in other activities there.
ny: Cox anati: "Tinaona kuti anthu amene anali ndi malo atatu anali ogwirizana kwambiri ndi anthu a m'dera lawo.

en: They are much more trusting of their neighbors. There's a whole great array of positive social outcomes that were connected to having a third place … and for a lot of Americans, it's a coffee shop or a cafe."
ny: Iwo amadalira kwambiri anansi awo. Pali zotsatira zabwino zambiri za chikhalidwe zomwe zimagwirizana ndi kukhala ndi malo achitatu... ndipo kwa anthu ambiri a ku America, ndi malo ogulitsira khofi kapena malo odyera".

en: What coffee shops have in their favor is that they can be found almost everywhere, all over the country, and anyone who wants to can stop by regularly.
ny: Malo ogulitsira khofi ali ndi mwayi wakuti amapezeka pafupifupi kulikonse, m'dziko lonse, ndipo aliyense amene akufuna akhoza kupita nthawi zonse.

en: And many are open most days of the week.
ny: Ndipo ambiri amakhala otseguka masiku ambiri a mlungu.

en: Cox says even brief coffee shop encounters can increase a sense of belonging.
ny: Cox ananena kuti ngakhale kukumana kwa kanthawi kochepa ndi anthu a m'malesitilanti kungachititse kuti anthu azikhala ndi mtima wofuna kukhala nawo.

en: "I think there's a lot of potential here, and a lot of it is unrealized potential," Cox says.
ny: Cox anati: "Ndikuganiza kuti pali zinthu zambiri zimene zingachitike m'dzikoli, ndipo zambiri mwa zinthu zimenezi sizinachitikepo".

en: "But in terms of what they could do, there's a lot there.
ny: "Koma ponena za zimene akanatha kuchita, pali zambiri kumeneko.

en: I've been in places where the same group of folks come in there to play chess.
ny: Ndakhala m'malo amene anthu amodzi amabwera kudzasewera chess.

en: Or they have their informal bunch of retirees. … They just got together, and they talked and chatted and caught up with each other. … I don't know where else they would have gone — maybe a church, but maybe not — to share information, to encourage each other to maybe get involved in an activity.
ny: Kapena ali ndi gulu lawo la anthu omwe ali pa ntchito yopuma pantchito.... Iwo anangopangana, ndipo analankhula ndi kucheza ndi kukumana wina ndi mnzake.... Sindikudziwa kumene iwo akanapita  mwina tchalitchi, koma mwina osati  kugawana zambiri, kulimbikitsana kuti mwina nawo ntchito.

en: And I think that is what is so powerful about coffee shops."
ny: Ndipo ndikuganiza kuti ndicho chimene chili champhamvu kwambiri m'malesitilanti".

en: What US Mayors Are Most Worried About After the Pandemic
ny: Zimene Alendo a ku United States Akuda nkhawa Kwambiri Pambuyo pa Mliriwu

en: Americas mayors are most concerned about the lingering mental health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a nationwide survey of 126 mayors conducted during the summer of 2021.
ny: Akuluakulu a boma ku America akuda nkhawa kwambiri ndi zovuta zomwe matenda a COVID-19 akubweretsa m'maganizo, malinga ndi kafukufuku wadziko lonse wa meya 126 omwe adachitika mchilimwe cha 2021.

en: The respondents headed cities with at least 75,000 residents. The local leaders are still focused on traditional issues such as violent crime, the economy and infrastructure, but they are most concerned about the pandemics long-term impact on the mental health of their constituents.
ny: Oyankhawo adawongolera mizinda yokhala ndi anthu osachepera 75,000. Atsogoleri am'deralo akuyang'anabe nkhani zachikhalidwe monga upandu wankhanza, chuma ndi zomangamanga, koma akuda nkhawa kwambiri ndi zovuta za mliriwu pa thanzi lamaganizidwe la anthu omwe amawavota.

en: Mental health was top of mind for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as mayor of Broward County, Florida, in November 2021.
ny: Moyo wa maganizo unali wofunika kwambiri kwa Michael Udine pamene analumbira kukhala meya wa Broward County, Florida, mu November 2021.

en: "Everything that was a potential issue pre-pandemic has pretty much been exacerbated by the pandemic," he says. "There were issues going into the pandemic, and it was becoming more and more important on everyone's radar screen about the mental health of people of all ages. And I think the pandemic pretty much supercharged those issues."
ny: Iye anati: "Zinthu zonse zimene zinali zovuta kwambiri pa nthawi ya mliriwu zinkawonjezereka chifukwa cha mliriwu. Panali mavuto ena amene ankachititsa kuti anthu azidziwa za matendawa ndipo anthu a misinkhu yonse azidziwa kuti matendawa ndi ofunika kwambiri".

en: It is not unusual for large outbreaks of disease to have a negative impact on mental health, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reports that rates of anxiety and depressive disorders among adults increased during the pandemic.
ny: Malinga ndi lipoti la Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, si zachilendo kuti matenda aakulu amakhudza kwambiri thanzi la anthu, ndipo anthu akuluakulu akuvutika maganizo kwambiri.

en: The pandemic has also adversely influenced the emotional and mental health of about one-third of Americas youth.
ny: Mliriwu wavulazanso maganizo a achinyamata pafupifupi gawo limodzi mwa atatu a ku America.

en: "What we've seen is just such anxiety, kids who wouldn't ordinarily have a meltdown, because it's so much change and difficulty adjusting to transitions," Maryland psychologist Mary Karapetian Alvord told VOA last month. "We've also seen a lot more sadness and depression."
ny: "Zimene taona ndi nkhaŵa, ana amene kaŵirikaŵiri sakhala ndi vuto la kusokonezeka maganizo, chifukwa chakuti pali kusintha kwakukulu ndi zovuta zozoloŵera kusintha", anatero katswiri wa maganizo wa ku Maryland Mary Karapetian Alvord ku Voice of America mwezi watha. "Tawonanso chisoni ndi kuvutika maganizo zambiri".

en: Early on in the pandemic, mayors were more focused on city operations, budget shortfalls and the threat the pandemic posed to small businesses, according to David Glick, an associate professor of political science at Boston University and a co-author of the 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors.
ny: Kumayambiriro kwa mliriwu, ma mayor anali okhazikika kwambiri pa ntchito za mzinda, kusowa kwa bajeti komanso chiwopsezo chomwe mliriwu udayambitsa mabizinesi ang'onoang'ono, malinga ndi David Glick, pulofesa wothandizirana ndi sayansi yandale ku Boston University komanso wolemba nawo kafukufuku wa Mayors wa Menino wa 2021.

en: "Some of those concerns still remain, but what we saw more of in 2021 … is concern about some of the long-term impacts on individual residents," Glick says. "Concerns about polarization over vaccines and just people being pushed to their limits … and certainly less on their city budgets and revenues and having to cut programs and some of those types of things that were probably more top of mind earlier in the pandemic."
ny: "Zinthu zina zomwe zikuda nkhawazo zikadalipobe, koma zomwe tawona zambiri mu 2021... ndizo nkhawa zakukhudzidwa kwakanthawi kwa anthu okhalamo", akutero Glick. "Zowopsa zakugwedezeka kwa katemera komanso anthu okhawo omwe akukumana ndi malire awo... ndipo ndithudi zochepa pa bajeti yawo yamatawuni ndi ndalama zawo komanso kuyenera kudula mapulogalamu ndi zina mwazinthu zomwe mwina zinali zofunika kwambiri m'maganizo koyambirira kwa mliriwu".

en: Over half of mayors, 52%, are worried about "lingering mental health challenges and trauma," according to the survey. Additionally, more than one-third of mayors, 37%, are worried about learning loss among young people.
ny: Kafukufukuyu anasonyeza kuti anthu oposa hafu ya anthu amene ali ndi udindowu, omwe ndi 52%, akuda nkhawa ndi "zoopsa za matenda a m'maganizo komanso mavuto amene amabwera chifukwa cha matendawa".

en: "Second only to mental health and trauma, and they're probably not totally independent concerns," Glick says. "It is part of that shift of mayors concerns from immediate threats to businesses closing and people getting sick, to some of these longer-term consequences that are going to persist in the future. And learning loss among their students, theyre worried it's going to persist for many, many, many years into the future. It's hard to make up for."
ny: "Chachiwiri ndi thanzi la maganizo ndi kuvulala, ndipo mwina si nkhani zodziimira palokha", akutero Glick. "Ndi mbali ya kusintha kwa madokotala a boma nkhawa kuchokera ku chiopsezo cha posachedwapa kutseka mabizinesi ndi anthu kudwala, kuti ena a zotsatira izi yaitali yaitali kuti adzapitirizabe m'tsogolo. Ndipo kutayika kuphunzira pakati pa ophunzira awo, iwo akuda nkhawa izo adzapitirizabe kwa zaka zambiri, zambiri, zambiri m'tsogolo. Ndi zovuta kubwezera".

en: According to the survey, other top concerns for Americas mayors include the financial insecurity of low-income residents (33%), the closing of small businesses (29%) and increased crime and violence (26%).
ny: Malinga ndi kafukufukuyu, nkhawa zina zazikulu kwa meya a ku America ndi kusatetezeka kwa ndalama kwa anthu okhala ndi ndalama zochepa (33%), kutseka mabizinesi ang'onoang'ono (29%) ndi kuwonjezeka kwa umbanda ndi chiwawa (26%).

en: Just 7% of mayors are worried about the shift to remote work and the long-term impact that could have on outmigration — people moving away from their cities.
ny: Anthu 7% okha a meya ndi amene akuda nkhawa ndi kusintha kwa ntchito yakutali komanso zotsatira zake pa nthawi yaitali pa anthu amene akuthawa m'mizinda yawo.

en: The $350 billion in funding from the American Rescue Plan to local and state governments could help mayors address some of their concerns. The survey found that 78% of mayors believe the money will allow them to make meaningful change.
ny: Kafukufukuyu anasonyeza kuti anthu 78 pa 100 alionse amene anafunsidwa ananena kuti ndalamazo zingawathandize kusintha zinthu.

en: "What we're seeing is a large majority are using it for things they consider to be transformative and will make major changes to their cities," Glick says, "instead of feeling obligated or feeling the necessity to use it to plug up over-budget gaps to keep the doors open and the lights on."
ny: "Tikudziŵa kuti anthu ambiri akugwiritsa ntchito ndalamazo pa zinthu zimene amaziona kuti ndi zongochititsa kusintha ndipo zidzasintha kwambiri mizinda yawo", akutero Glick, "m'malo momva kuti ali ndi udindo kapena kuti akufunikira kuzigwiritsa ntchito kuti athetse mavuto amene ali m'boma la ndalama kuti zitseko zisatsegulidwe ndiponso magetsi aziwala".

en: Young Compete Against Old in Hottest US Rental Market in a Decade
ny: Achinyamata Akupikisana ndi Achikulire pa Msika Wopatsa Malonda wa ku America pa Zaka Zokwana 10

en: Renting an apartment can be a challenge for new college graduates who are facing the hottest U.S. rental market in a decade, along with some unexpected competition from millennials — people aged 24 to 40 — and even baby boomers — the over-57 club.
ny: Kuchita lendi nyumba kungakhale kovuta kwa omaliza maphunziro a koleji atsopano omwe akukumana ndi msika wotentha kwambiri wa lendi ku US m'zaka khumi, limodzi ndi mpikisano wosayembekezereka kuchokera kwa millennials  anthu azaka 24 mpaka 40  ngakhale ana omwe ali ndi zaka za baby boom  gulu la anthu okalamba a zaka 57.

en: "You have aging millennials who are creating families who should be moving from rental situations into ownership but, because of the lack of housing supply, that has been stopped in a lot of instances. And so, what you see is the aging millennial population continues to rent," says Doug Ressler, manager of business intelligence at Yardi-Matrix, a commercial real estate data and research firm.
ny: "Muli ndi anthu okalamba omwe akupanga mabanja omwe ayenera kusamukira ku malo ogulitsira nyumba koma chifukwa cha kusowa kwa nyumba, zimenezi zaletsedwa nthawi zambiri. Choncho, zimene mukuona n'zakuti anthu okalamba akupitirizabe kubwereka nyumba", akutero Doug Ressler, woyang'anira ntchito za nzeru za bizinesi ku Yardi-Matrix, kampani yopanga deta ndi kafukufuku wa malo ogulitsa katundu.

en: "It's not just about millennials, it's not just about [Gen] Z [people under 24], we also see that boomers are making a transition, he added. "Their percentage of moving into rental properties is growing in the last five years."
ny: Iye anawonjezera kuti: "Si za mibadwo ya zaka chikwi chimodzi yokha, si za [Mizimu ya Z] [anthu osakwana zaka 24], timaonanso kuti anthu amene ali m'gulu la anthu otchuka akupita patsogolo. "Chiwerengero cha anthu amene amapita kukakhala m'nyumba zogona chikuwonjezeka m'zaka zisanu zapitazi".

en: There are a variety of reasons older people are opting for rentals, according to Ressler.
ny: Malinga ndi kunena kwa Ressler, pali zifukwa zosiyanasiyana zimene anthu okalamba amasankhira lendi.

en: "They've lived in a home for so long and they want to be able to reduce their expenses on a fixed income," he says. "They want to live in a social cohort, like a retirement community, and things like that where it's much more socially amenable to them."
ny: Iye anati: "Akakhala m'nyumba kwa nthaŵi yaitali kwambiri ndipo amafuna kuti athe kuchepetsa ndalama zimene amawononga pa ndalama zimene amalipira. Iwo amafuna kukhala m'gulu la anthu, monga anthu amene akukhala m'nyumba yopuma pantchito, ndi zinthu zina zotero, zimene zimawathandiza kwambiri".

en: The asking price of apartment rentals was up 10.7% in September 2021 compared to last year at the same time, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).
ny: Mtengo wofunsira nyumba yobwereka nyumba unakwera 10.7% mu Seputembara 2021 poyerekeza ndi chaka chatha panthawi yomweyo, malinga ndi National Association of Realtors (NAR).

en: "It's a hot market. We have never seen this market so hot in the last decade," says Gay Cororaton, NARs senior economist and director of housing and commercial research. "The average rent growth, year-over-year, is about 3-to-5%. We're seeing 11% rent growth now, so, clearly, way above trends weve had in the past."
ny: "Ndi msika wotentha. Sitinaonepo msika wotentha chonchi m'zaka khumi zapitazi", akutero Gay Cororaton, katswiri wa zachuma wamkulu wa NARs ndi mkulu wa kafukufuku wa nyumba ndi malonda. "Kuwonjezeka kwa ndalama za lendi, chaka ndi chaka, kuli pafupifupi 3-5% ndipo tikuwona kukula kwa ndalama za lendi kwa 11% tsopano, kotero, momveka bwino, kuposa momwe tinalililili m'mbuyomu".

en: Renters are feeling the squeeze because the COVID-19 pandemic caused supply chain issues, slowing down home building in the United States. Instead of the usual 5-to-6 month supply of available single-family homes, supply dropped below two months in January 2021. The lack of housing supply means millennials are having a harder time buying a single-family home, which has been the traditional trajectory in the past.
ny: Anthu omwe ali ndi nyumba amadzimva kuti akumanidwa chifukwa cha mliri wa COVID-19 womwe unayambitsa mavuto azogulitsira nyumba, zomwe zimachepetsa ntchito yomanga nyumba ku United States. M'malo mwa kupereka kwa miyezi 5 mpaka 6 kwa nyumba za mabanja amodzi, zopereka zidatsika pansi pa miyezi iwiri mu Januware 2021.

en: "The whole building industry was beset by supply chain issues," Cororaton says. "Shipments couldn't come in, the price of lumber was rising, manufacturing slowed, workers could not come in [to work], so you have shortages of frames, appliances. So, essentially, just a short supply."
ny: Cororaton anati: "M'makampani onse omanga nyumba munali mavuto ambiri chifukwa cha mavuto a m'gulu la katundu. Zogulitsa sizinathe, mitengo ya mitengo inali kukwera, ntchito yopanga inali yochepa, antchito sakanatha kubwera [kukachita ntchito], choncho mulibe zipilala, zipangizo, choncho, kwenikweni, kunalibe katundu wambiri".

en: The housing supply got even tighter during the pandemic as more investors put their money into housing, according to Cororaton, while existing homeowners looked for second homes.
ny: Kupereka nyumba kunakhala kovuta kwambiri panthawi ya mliriwu chifukwa ndalama zambiri zimagulitsidwa m'nyumba, malinga ndi Cororaton, pomwe eni nyumba omwe alipo kale adafufuza nyumba yachiwiri.

en: "With the pandemic, there was also a big demand for second homes, for vacation homes. Typically, vacation homes accounted for just about 5% [of the market]," she says. "Early this summer they rose to about 8%. So again, strong demand and strong imbalance of demand and supply caused home prices to rise, made them less affordable."
ny: Iye anati: "Poyamba m'chilimwe uno, nyumbazi zinakwera kufika pafupifupi 8%. Choncho, chifukwa cha kuchepa kwa mitengo ya nyumba, komanso chifukwa cha kusamvana kwa zinthu, mitengo ya nyumba inakula, moti anthu sanakwanitse kugula nyumba".

en: The hottest rental markets right now are in the West and South. More renters are moving to Dallas and Houston in Texas, followed by Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; and Washington, D.C., according to NAR.
ny: Misika yotentha kwambiri yobwereka pakadali pano ili kumadzulo ndi kumwera. Ambiri omwe amapita ku Dallas ndi Houston ku Texas, akutsatiridwa ndi Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; ndi Washington, D.C., malinga ndi NAR.

en: Cororaton expects the coming year to be a little better but says the housing shortage is likely to continue for the next few years.
ny: Cororaton akuyembekeza kuti chaka chamawa chidzakhala chabwino kwambiri koma akuti kusoŵa kwa nyumba kungakhalebe kwa zaka zingapo zikubwerazi.

en: "You know, the old adage of moving from rentals into homeownership, that whole polemic may be changing," says Ressler. "The sweet spot was always the millennials, and now the millennials are being replaced by the [Gen] Zs, but the millennials are staying longer and the Zs are coming on board, and now you've got the demographic of the boomers … What it means is a very profitable and dynamic [rental] market that's going to continue to grow."
ny: "Mukumvetsa, mwambi wakale wosamukira ku lendi kupita ku lendi, kuti mkangano wonsewo ukhoza kusintha", akutero Ressler. "Malo abwino anali nthaŵi zonse a mibadwo ya zaka chikwi, ndipo tsopano mibadwo ya zaka chikwi akubwezeretsedwa ndi [Male) Zs, koma mibadwo ya zaka chikwi ikhala motalikirapo ndipo Zs akubwera, ndipo tsopano muli ndi anthu a boomers... Chimene zikutanthauza ndi msika wopindulitsa kwambiri ndi wolimba [wolipira] umene udzapitiriza kukula".

en: Are COVID-19 Restrictions Stunting Children’s Immune Systems?
ny: Kodi Kuletsa kwa COVID-19 Kumapangitsa Kuti Machitidwe A chitetezo cha mthupi A Ana Achepe?

en: Some medical experts have expressed concern that COVID-19 preventative measures, like masking and remote schooling, are potentially weakening childrens immune systems by shielding them from the usual childhood illnesses.
ny: Akatswiri ena azachipatala asonyeza nkhawa kuti njira zotetezera COVID-19, monga kuvala masks ndi kupita kusukulu kutali, zikhoza kufooketsa chitetezo cha mthupi cha ana powateteza ku matenda wamba a ana.

en: "There are a lot of reasons to believe that kids need to be exposed to things to keep their immunity complex, so that should they encounter something very dangerous, they have aspects of their immunity that might cross over and help protect them against those things," says Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular, cellular and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder.
ny: "Pali zifukwa zambiri zokhulupirira kuti ana ayenera kuoneredwa zinthu zina kuti ateteze chitetezo chawo, kotero kuti ngati angakumane ndi chinachake choopsa kwambiri, iwo angakhale ndi mbali za chitetezo chawo cha mthupi zimene zingawachititse kuti asatetezedwe ku zinthu zimenezo", akutero Sara Sawyer, pulofesa wa sayansi ya maselo, maselo ndi chitukuko ku Yunivesite ya Colorado ku Boulder.

en: At birth, vulnerable infants get antibodies from their mothers breast milk, which helps protect them until they can build their own immunity.
ny: Ana amene ali pachiwopsezo chobadwa amatenga maantibodi a mkaka wa amayi awo, ndipo zimenezi zimawateteza mpaka atakhala ndi chitetezo cha m'thupi.

en: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.  "They're doing that because they're sampling the environment and building their immunity. That's an evolutionary trait," Sawyer says.
ny: Sawyer anati: "Ana amayamba kuika zinthu m'kamwa mwawo atangomvetsa mmene angagwiritsire ntchito zinthuzo.

en: "Theyre exposing their body to germs in a certain, level way to build their immunity.
ny: "Amakhala akuika thupi lawo m'manja mwa tizilombo toyambitsa matenda m'njira inayake kuti ateteze chitetezo chawo.

en: So, some people would argue that childhood illnesses, like colds and stomach bugs, build our immunity so that when more dangerous things come along, we're prepared and we don't get as sick from those more dangerous things."
ny: Choncho anthu ena amanena kuti matenda a ana, monga chimfine ndi tizilombo toyambitsa matenda, amatithandiza kuti tisataye mtima kwambiri kuti zinthu zoopsa zikadzachitika, tikhale okonzeka ndipo tisadwale matenda oopsa".

en: Even before the pandemic, epidemiological evidence suggested that children in more developed countries, where handwashing and the use of sanitizer are more prevalent, might have less-developed immune systems compared to kids in developing nations who are routinely exposed to more bacteria, viruses and allergens.
ny: Ngakhale mliriwu usanachitike, umboni wa matendawa unasonyeza kuti ana a m'mayiko otukuka kwambiri, kumene kusamba m'manja ndi kugwiritsa ntchito mankhwala ophera m'manja n'kofala kwambiri, angakhale ndi chitetezo cha m'thupi chochepa poyerekeza ndi ana a m'mayiko osauka omwe nthawi zambiri amavutika ndi mabakiteriya, mavairasi ndi zinthu zina zochititsa matenda.

en: This makes kids in more industrialized countries more vulnerable to developing autoimmune diseases, according to whats known as the "hygiene hypothesis."
ny: Zimenezi zimachititsa kuti ana a m'mayiko ena otukuka kwambiri asakumane ndi matenda a chitetezo cha m'thupi, malinga ndi zimene anthu ena amati ndi "chiphunzitso cha ukhondo".

en: "The hygiene hypothesis is actually quite controversial because it's thought that our exposure to microbes isn't the only factor," says Cody Warren, a virologist and immunologist who is a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Colorado Boulder.
ny: "Chiphunzitso chakuti anthu ali ndi ukhondo ndi chotsutsana kwambiri chifukwa chakuti anthu amaganiza kuti si chifukwa chokha chimene chimayambitsa matendawa", akutero Cody Warren, katswiri wa za tizilombo toyambitsa matenda ndiponso wa matenda amene ali ndi digiri ya pambuyo pa maphunziro a digiri ya ku yunivesite ya Colorado ku Boulder.

en: "A lot of this could also be dictated by genetics, diet, and the environment that we live in.
ny: "Zambiri mwa zimenezi zingakhudzidwe ndi majini, zakudya, ndi malo amene tikukhala.

en: That also shapes our immune system… it's a real multifactorial thing that we can't fully account for just by wearing masks.
ny: Chimenechi chimakhalanso ndi chitetezo chathu cha m'thupi. Ndi chinthu chenicheni cha zinthu zambiri chimene sitingathe kuchifotokoza bwinobwino mwa kuvala masks.

en: There are other things that go into that equation."
ny: Pali zinthu zina zimene zimagwirizana ndi zimenezi".

en: Warren, the father of three young children, says spending lots of time outdoors is one way to balance the negatives of isolation.
ny: Warren, bambo wa ana atatu, akuti kukhala panja nthaŵi yaitali ndi njira imodzi yochepetsera mavuto a kudzipatula.

en: "Just exploring microbes in the environment also is benefiting [and] training our immune system," Warren says. "Our immune systems get trained through the foods that we eat, which also have microorganisms on them.
ny: Warren anati: "Kungofufuza tizilombo toyambitsa matenda m'chilengedwe kumapindulanso [ndi] kuphunzitsa chitetezo chathu cha m'thupi.

en: And so, despite the fact that we've kind of been hunkered down a little bit, I do feel that our immune systems will catch up."
ny: Choncho ngakhale kuti anthu ena amatichititsa kuti tisakhale ndi chitetezo cha m'thupi, ndimaganiza kuti chitetezo chathu cha m'thupi chidzatha".

en: There are other things parents can do, he says, to boost their childrens immune systems during pandemic times.  "One of the most important things you can do is just to stay up to date on vaccines.
ny: Iye anati pali zinthu zina zimene makolo angachite kuti athandize ana awo kukhala ndi chitetezo cha m'thupi m'nthaŵi ya mliriwu. "Chinthu chimodzi chofunika kwambiri chimene mungachite n'chakuti muziphunzira zonse zokhudza katemera.

en: That's one of the best ways that we have to train our immune systems," Warren says.
ny: Warren anati: "N'chifukwa chake anthu ambiri amaganiza kuti zimenezi n'zofunika kwambiri.

en: "But also, equally important is making sure our children have a good diet and they regulate stress.
ny: "Koma n'kofunikanso kuonetsetsa kuti ana athu ali ndi zakudya zabwino ndiponso kuti akuchepetsa nkhawa.

en: It's been well documented that both of those — having a good diet, a less stressful environment — can have a positive impact on our immune system."
ny: Zatsimikiziridwa bwino kuti onse aŵiri amene ali ndi zakudya zabwino, malo osapanikizika kwambiri, akhoza kukhala ndi zotsatira zabwino pa chitetezo chathu cha m'thupi".

en: Once public health officials say masks are no longer necessary, Sawyer thinks pointing out the positives of putting our masks away could reassure hesitant parents who worry about their children getting sick.
ny: Akuluakulu a zaumoyo akangoti masks sakhalanso ofunika, Sawyer akuganiza kuti kusonyeza ubwino wa kuika masks athu kutali kungalimbikitse makolo amene akuopa kuti ana awo adwala.

en: "Maybe we should have a public conversation about the possible reasons to take that mask off, if they are in school, and get back to the normal repertoire of relatively safe childhood illnesses," she says.
ny: Iye anati: "Mwina tingachite bwino kukambirana pagulu za zifukwa zimene zingachititse kuti ana athu azivulala ngati ali kusukulu, ndi kubwerera ku nkhani yachibadwa ya matenda otetezeka a ana".

en: "The plus side of childhood illnesses is that they can build up that hornet's nest of immunity that could protect kids against new things that then come along."
ny: "Chimene chimapangitsa kuti ana azidwala matenda a ana ndi chakuti amatha kukhala ndi chitetezo cholimba cha matendawa. Zimenezi zimateteza ana ku zinthu zatsopano zimene zimabwera".

en: US Quietly Expands Asylum Limits While Preparing to End Them
ny: US Ikukula M'mbuyo M'mbuyo Pamene Ikukonzekera Kuzimitsa

en: The Biden administration has begun expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans to Mexico under pandemic-related powers to deny migrants a chance to seek asylum, expanding use of the rule even as it publicly says it has been trying to unwind it, officials said Wednesday.
ny: Boma la Biden layamba kuthamangitsa anthu aku Cuba ndi a ku Nicaragua ku Mexico pansi pa mphamvu zokhudzana ndi mliriwu kuti alandire mwayi wopempha chitetezo kwa anthu othawa kwawo, ndikuwonjezera kugwiritsa ntchito lamuloli ngakhale kuti likuwonetsa poyera kuti likuyesera kulichotsa, akuluakulu adati Lachitatu.

en: The U.S. struck agreement with Mexico to expel up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans a day from three locations: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; and Rio Grande Valley, Texas, according to a U.S. official with direct knowledge of the effort.
ny: Malinga ndi zimene mkulu wina wa boma la United States amene akudziwa zimenezi ananena, dziko la United States linagwirizana ndi dziko la Mexico kuti lithamangitse anthu 100 a ku Cuba ndi anthu 20 a ku Nicaragua tsiku lililonse kuchokera m'madera atatu awa: ku San Diego, El Paso, ku Texas, ndi ku Rio Grande Valley, ku Texas.

en: The expulsions began April 27 and will end May 22, the official told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the agreement has not been made public.
ny: Kuchotsedwa kwa anthu kumeneku kunayamba pa 27 April ndipo kudzatha pa 22 May, mkuluyo anauza Associated Press kuti asadziwe dzina lake chifukwa chakuti mgwirizanowu sunalengezedwe.

en: They are carried out under Title 42 authority, a public health law that has been used to expel migrants on grounds of preventing spread of COVID-19. Title 42 is due to expire May 23, unless a judge intervenes.
ny: Zimachitika pansi pa udindo wa Title 42, lamulo laumoyo wa anthu lomwe lakhala likugwiritsidwa ntchito kuthamangitsa alendo chifukwa choletsa kufalikira kwa COVID-19. Title 42 ikutha pa Meyi 23, pokhapokha woweruza atalowerera.

en: The U.S. and Mexico agreed April 26 to a very limited number of expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans, according to a high-level Mexican official who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment publicly.
ny: Dziko la United States ndi Mexico anavomera pa April 26 kuti anthu a ku Cuba ndi a ku Nicaragua achotsedwe m'dziko lawo, malinga ndi mkulu wina wa boma la Mexico amene analankhula popanda kudziwika chifukwa chakuti sanaloledwe kuyankhapo poyera.

en: It was prompted by higher numbers of migrants from those two countries coming to the U.S. border.
ny: Zimenezi zinachitika chifukwa chakuti anthu ochokera m'mayiko awiriwa ankafika ku malire a dziko la United States.

en: Mexico also took into account that the U.S. government had started processing visas in Cuba again, the official said. Mexico had also begun processing visas for Cubans.
ny: Mexico inaganizanso kuti boma la United States layambiranso kukonza ma visa ku Cuba, anatero mkuluyo. Mexico inayambanso kukonza ma visa kwa anthu a ku Cuba.

en: Another Mexican official, also not authorized to comment publicly, confirmed that up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans were being expelled from San Diego under Title 42.
ny: Ofesi ina ya ku Mexico, yomwe sinali ndi chilolezo chofotokoza poyera, inatsimikizira kuti anthu 100 a ku Cuba ndi anthu 20 a ku Nicaragua akuchotsedwa ku San Diego pansi pa Mutu 42.

en: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
ny: Dipatimenti ya Chitetezo cha M'dziko la United States sinayankhe mwamsanga pempho loti apereke ndemanga.

en: Until last week, Mexico only agreed to take Guatemalans, Hondurans and El Salvadorans — in addition to Mexicans — under Title 42 authority. Other nationalities are subject to Title 42 but costs, strained diplomatic ties and other considerations often make it difficult to send them back to their home countries.
ny: Mpaka sabata yatha, Mexico idavomera kutenga anthu aku Guatemala, Honduras ndi El Salvador  kuwonjezera pa anthu aku Mexico  pansi pa ulamuliro wa Title 42. Mitundu ina imatsatiridwa ndi Title 42 koma ndalama, ubale wovuta ndi zinthu zina zimawapangitsa kukhala ovuta kuwatumiza kwawo.

en: It's next to impossible for the U.S. to expel migrants to Cuba or Nicaragua because of poor relations with those governments. That has posed a challenge for the Biden administration as more people from those countries seek haven in the United States.
ny: Ndizosatheka kuti US ichotse alendo ku Cuba kapena Nicaragua chifukwa cha ubale woipa ndi maboma amenewo. Izi zakhala zovuta kwa oyang'anira a Biden chifukwa anthu ambiri ochokera kumayiko amenewo akufunafuna malo osungirako anthu ku United States.

en: Cubans were stopped by U.S. authorities more than 32,000 times on the Mexican border in March, double the number in February and more than five times October's count, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Nicaragua eased travel restrictions from Cuba in November, making it easier for Cubans to continue by land to the U.S. border. Most enter the U.S. in or near Yuma, Arizona, and Del Rio, Texas.
ny: Malinga ndi US Customs and Border Protection, anthu aku Cuba anaimitsidwa ndi akuluakulu a boma la United States maulendo oposa 32,000 pa malire a Mexico mu March, kuwirikiza kawiri chiwerengero cha anthu omwe anafika mu February ndipo kuwirikiza kawiri chiwerengero cha anthu omwe anafika mu October. Nicaragua inachepetsa zoletsa kuyenda kuchokera ku Cuba mu November, zomwe zinapangitsa kuti zikhale zosavuta kuti anthu aku Cuba apitirize kuyenda m'dzikoli mpaka kumalire a United States. Ambiri amalowa m'dziko la United States ku Yuma, Arizona, ndi Del Rio, Texas.

en: Nicaraguans were stopped more than 16,000 times in March, more than double September's level. The vast majority enter in South Texas.
ny: Anthu a ku Nicaragua analetsedwa maulendo oposa 16,000 mu March, kuwirikiza kawiri kuchuluka kwa anthu a mu September.

en: Lifting Title 42 has proved controversial as midterm elections near, even for Biden's Democratic Party, amid concerns that the U.S. is unprepared for an anticipated increase in migrants seeking asylum. Authorities stopped migrants more than 221,000 times in March, the highest mark in 22 years.
ny: Kuchotsa Mutu 42 kwawonetsedwa ngati kosamvetsetseka pomwe chisankho chapakati pa nthawi yayandikira, ngakhale kwa Democratic Party ya Biden, pakati pa nkhawa kuti US siyokonzeka pakuwonjezeka kwa alendo omwe akufuna chitetezo. Akuluakulu adatseka alendo nthawi zopitilira 221,000 mu Marichi, chiwonetsero chapamwamba kwambiri mzaka 22.

en: The White House and Homeland Security Department have publicly stood behind the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's decision to end the measure because it could no longer be justified on grounds of protecting public health.
ny: Nyumba Yoyera ndi Dipatimenti ya Chitetezo cha Mkati mwa Dziko zatsimikizira poyera kuti mabungwe a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention asankha kuthetsa njira imeneyi chifukwa chakuti sichikhala choyenera chifukwa cha kuteteza thanzi la anthu.

en: But the practice of expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans runs counter to the administration's public statements that it was phasing out use of the pandemic powers to prepare for May 23.
ny: Koma chizoloŵezi chochotsa anthu a ku Cuba ndi ku Nicaragua chikutsutsana ndi zimene boma la Nicaragua linalengeza kuti likuchotsa pang'onopang'ono kugwiritsa ntchito mphamvu za mliriwu pokonzekera 23 May.

en: The U.S. has expelled migrants more than 1.8 million times under Title 42 authority since March 2020, effectively overriding rights to seek asylum under U.S. law and international treaty. In doing so, migrants are not subject to immigration law, which include rights to seek protection from persecution at home.
ny: US yatulutsa othawa kwawo maulendo opitilira 1.8 miliyoni malinga ndi ulamuliro wa Title 42 kuyambira Marichi 2020, zomwe zimapangitsa ufulu wopempha chitetezo malinga ndi malamulo aku US ndi mgwirizano wapadziko lonse. Potero, othawa kwawo samakhala pansi pa malamulo obwerera kwawo, omwe akuphatikizapo ufulu wopempha chitetezo ku chizunzo kunyumba.

en: The administration said in court filings that it began processing more Central American adults under immigration laws after the CDC's announcement on April 1. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that it couldn't start unwinding Title 42 while it was still in effect.
ny: Boma la boma linati m'mafayilo a khoti linayamba kusamalira anthu akuluakulu a ku Central America malinga ndi malamulo a anthu obwera kudziko lina pambuyo pa kulengeza kwa CDC pa April 1. Koma woweruza wa boma ku Louisiana analamula sabata yatha kuti silingathe kuyamba kuthetsa Title 42 pamene inali yogwirabe ntchito.

en: U.S. District Judge Robert Summerhays strongly criticized the CDC's decision, suggesting he would try to keep Title 42 in effect after May 23. A hearing is scheduled May 13 for oral arguments.
ny: Woweruza wa chigawo cha United States Robert Summerhays anatsutsa kwambiri chigamulo cha CDC, ponena kuti iye adzafuna kusunga Mutu 42 kukhala wogwira ntchito pambuyo pa May 23. Kumvetsera kwapangidwa pa May 13 kaamba ka zifukwa zamlomo.

en: Marisa Limon, senior director of advocacy and planning at the Hope Border Institute, said advocates began learning about expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans from El Paso on Monday and later confirmed the new practice with U.S. officials.
ny: Marisa Limon, mkulu wa bungwe loona za kulimbikitsa anthu komanso kukonzekera mapulani ku Hope Border Institute, ananena kuti anthu omwe akulimbikitsa anthu kuti azitha kuthawa ku El Paso anayamba kuphunzira za kuthamangitsidwa kwa anthu a ku Cuba ndi ku Nicaragua Lolemba ndipo kenako anatsimikizira kuti zimenezi ndi zoona kwa akuluakulu a boma la United States.

en: Limon said the administration is "trying to get every last bit out of Title 42" before it expires. She called it "sobering" but consistent with the administration's efforts to have other countries in the Western hemisphere take more responsibility for hosting people fleeing their homes.
ny: Limon adati boma "likuyesera kuchotsa gawo lililonse la Title 42" lisanathe. Iye adati ndi "zosokoneza" koma mogwirizana ndi zoyesayesa za boma kuti mayiko ena akumadzulo atenge udindo waukulu wolandira anthu othawa kwawo.

en: Mexico Relocates Migrant Camp; Haitians Appear at Border
ny: Mexico Yasintha Malo a Anthu Othawa kwawo; Anthu a ku Haiti Akuonekera pa Mphepete mwa Dziko Lonse

en: Mexican authorities said Tuesday they have relocated a migrant camp that sprung up in a park in the border city of Reynosa, moving about 2,000 people from Central America and Haiti to a shelter in the city, across the border from McAllen, Texas.
ny: Akuluakulu a boma la Mexico analengeza Lachiwiri kuti asuntha msasa wa anthu othawa kwawo womwe unakhazikitsidwa m'mapaki mumzinda wa Reynosa, womwe uli pafupi ndi malire a dziko la Mexico, ndipo anthu pafupifupi 2,000 ochokera ku Central America ndi Haiti anasamukira kumalo ena okhala mumzindawu, kudutsa malire a McAllen, ku Texas.

en: The camp of migrants mainly from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Haiti sprung up after U.S. officials, citing the pandemic, invoked a health rule that denies migrants a chance to seek asylum.
ny: Mzinda wa anthu othawa kwawo makamaka ochokera ku Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras ndi Haiti unabwera pambuyo poti akuluakulu a ku US, potchula mliriwu, atchula lamulo laumoyo lomwe limaletsa othawa kwawo mwayi wopempha chitetezo.

en: Mexico's National Immigration Institute said the migrants were taken around midnight Monday to the shelter, which it said will have better hygiene and food services.
ny: Bungwe la National Immigration Institute ku Mexico linati anthuwa anatengedwa pa Lolemba pakati pausiku kupita ku malo osungirako anthu, ndipo linati malowa adzakhala ndi malo abwino ochitira zinthu komanso chakudya.

en: But on Monday, people in another border city, Nuevo Laredo, said hundreds of migrants, mainly Haitians, have streamed into that city, which is across the border from Laredo, Texas
ny: Koma Lolemba, anthu a mumzinda wina wa kumbali ya malire, Nuevo Laredo, anati anthu ambirimbiri, makamaka ochokera ku Haiti, alowa mumzindawu, womwe uli kutsidya lina la malire a Laredo, Texas.

en: The rush apparently started after the U.S. began processing some asylum-seekers there.
ny: Zikuoneka kuti anthu anayamba kuthamanga chifukwa chakuti dziko la United States linayamba kusamalira anthu ena ofuna kuthawa kwawo.

en: The Catholic bishop of Nuevo Laredo said Monday that migrant shelters there are overcrowded, with some migrants sleeping outside in tents.
ny: Bishopu wa Katolika wa ku Nuevo Laredo ananena Lolemba kuti malo obisalamo anthu othawa kwawo ali odzaza kwambiri, ndipo anthu ena othawa kwawo akugona panja m'mahema.

en: Bishop Enrique Sánchez Martínez said migrants started streaming into Nuevo Laredo in late April, though the city isn't usually popular among migrants, in part because it is dominated by the violent Northeast drug cartel.
ny: Bishop Enrique Sánchez Martínez anati anthu othawa kwawo anayamba kulowa mumzinda wa Nuevo Laredo chakumapeto kwa mwezi wa April, ngakhale kuti anthu ambiri sakonda kwambiri mzindawu, chifukwa chakuti umakhala ndi gulu la anthu ochita zachiwawa la zigawenga za kumpoto chakum'mawa kwa dzikoli.

en: "It is new for us because this is the last place they come, due to the conditions of our border, of our city, which are sometimes adverse for migrants," the bishop said. "But since they opened the door in the United States to asylum requests, a lot of them came in large groups."
ny: "Ndi malo atsopano kwa ife chifukwa chakuti ndi malo omaliza kumene amabwera, chifukwa cha mikhalidwe ya malire athu, a mzinda wathu, omwe nthaŵi zina amakhala ovuta kwa othawa kwawo", anatero bishopuyo. "Koma popeza anatsegula chitseko cha ku United States kaamba ka zopempha za chitetezo, ambiri a iwo anabwera m'magulu akulu".

en: Marvin Ajic, the director of the Casa Nazareth shelter, said that around April 16, Mexican authorities notified the shelters that the United States would resume processing asylum claims for humanitarian reasons.
ny: Marvin Ajic, mkulu wa nyumba yosungiramo anthu ya Casa Nazareth, ananena kuti pa April 16, akuluakulu a ku Mexico anauzanso malo osungiramo anthuwo kuti United States iyambiranso kukonza zopempha za chitetezo chifukwa cha zolinga za anthu.

en: The U.S. had begun allowing more people in, especially Central American adults, to prepare for lifting Title 42 — a pandemic-era health rule that denies migrants a chance to enter the U.S. seek asylum — on May 23. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that the government could not unwind the rule before the end date.
ny: US idayamba kulola anthu ambiri, makamaka akuluakulu aku Central America, kukonzekera kuchotsedwa kwa Title 42  lamulo laumoyo wa mliri womwe umakanira othawa kwawo mwayi wolowa ku US kufunafuna chitetezo  pa Meyi 23. Koma woweruza federal ku Louisiana adalamula sabata yatha kuti boma silingathe kuchotsa lamuloli lisanathe.

en: "The (Mexican) immigration officials organized things with the shelters, and the plan was to send people who had been waiting a long time, without any checks, basically anyone," Ajic said.
ny: "Akuluakulu a (Mexico) a zachibale anakonza zinthu ndi malo osungira anthu, ndipo cholinga chake chinali kutumiza anthu amene anali kuyembekezera kwa nthawi yaitali, popanda cheke, kwenikweni aliyense", adatero Ajic.

en: That apparently drew the attention of other migrants, including Haitians.
ny: Zikuoneka kuti zimenezi zinachititsa chidwi anthu ena omwe anasamukira ku Haiti, kuphatikizapo anthu a ku Haiti.

en: In September, similar rumors sparked a rush by about 15,000 mostly Haitian refugees to the Texas border, where they camped under a bridge. U.S. officials began large scale deportations of Haitians while also allowing thousands to remain in the U.S.
ny: M'mwezi wa September, mphekesera zofananazo zinayambitsa anthu pafupifupi 15,000 othawa kwawo, omwe ambiri anali achi Haiti, kupita ku malire a Texas, kumene anakaikira misasa yawo pansi pa mlatho.

en: Ajic warned migrants against coming to the border, noting the risks. On Monday, Mexico's National Immigration Institute said that so far this year, it has pulled the bodies of 19 immigrants from the Rio Grande, also known as the Rio Bravo.
ny: A Ajic anachenjeza anthu osamuka kuti asadzafike kumalire, poona kuti pali ngozi. Lolemba, bungwe la National Immigration Institute la ku Mexico linati chaka chino, anthu 19 omwe anasamuka kwawo anafa m'mbali mwa mtsinje wa Rio Grande, womwe umadziwikanso kuti Rio Bravo.

en: New US Rule Grants Automatic Work Permit Extensions to Noncitizens
ny: Lamulo Latsopano la ku US Likuwonjezera Ntchito Zogwira Ntchito kwa Anthu Osakhala nzika

en: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) announced Tuesday that it would automatically extend for 360 days the work permits of immigrants who applied to renew their work authorization amid the current backlog in processing times.
ny: US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) yalengeza Lachiwiri kuti idzawonjezera masiku 360 chilolezo chogwira ntchito kwa alendo omwe adafunsira kuti apititse patsogolo chilolezo chawo chogwira ntchito pakati pa nthawi yomwe ikuchedwa kukonza.

en: The new notice expands on the 180-day extension USCIS announced in November. It is expected to prevent about 260,000 immigrants from losing their work permits in the next 18 months. It will also give the agency extra time to clear applicants waiting in line, the agency said in a statement.
ny: Chidziwitso chatsopanochi chikuwonjezera masiku 180 omwe USCIS idalengeza mu Novembala. Zikuyembekezeka kuti chidzalepheretsa alendo pafupifupi 260,000 kutaya ziphaso zawo za ntchito m'miyezi 18 ikubwerayi.

en: "This temporary rule will provide those noncitizens otherwise eligible for the automatic extension an opportunity to maintain employment and provide critical support for their families while avoiding further disruption for U.S. employers," USCIS Director Ur M. Jaddou said in a statement.
ny: "Mkhalidwe wosavomerezeka umenewu udzapatsa anthu amene sali nzika za dzikoli mwayi wosunga ntchito yawo ndi kuthandiza mabanja awo pamene akupewa kusokoneza ntchito za mabwana a ku United States", anatero mkulu wa USCIS Ur M. Jaddou m'mawu.

en: The extension, which takes effect Wednesday, aims to stabilize operations for U.S. employers and help people with pending employment authorizations who have a job and are working in the U.S.
ny: Kuwonjezeka kwa ntchitoyi, komwe kudzayamba kugwira ntchito Lachitatu, cholinga chake ndi kulimbikitsa ntchito za olemba ntchito ku United States ndi kuthandiza anthu omwe ali ndi chilolezo chofuna kugwira ntchito ku United States omwe ali ndi ntchito ndipo akugwira ntchito ku United States

en: USCIS is the agency in charge of handling the nation's immigration paperwork. In recent years, it has struggled with backlogs, an issue made worse by the COVID-19 pandemic and budget shortfalls.
ny: USCIS ndi bungwe lomwe limayang'anira ntchito zolembera anthu ochokera kumayiko ena. M'zaka zaposachedwa, lakumana ndi mavuto ambiri, zomwe zaipitsidwa kwambiri ndi mliri wa COVID-19 komanso kusowa kwa bajeti.

en: In April, Jaddou told U.S. government officials during a congressional hearing that USCIS had 8.5 million pending immigration cases, including those seeking green cards and U.S. naturalization.
ny: Mu April, Jaddou anauza akuluakulu a boma la US pa msonkhano wa ku Congress kuti USCIS ili ndi milandu 8.5 miliyoni yofunsira anthu obwera kudziko lina, kuphatikizapo amene akufuna kupeza makadi obiriwira ndi dziko lina.

en: She said more than half of those pending cases were taking longer than the agency's normal processing times.
ny: Iye anati zoposa theka la milandu imene inalipo inali yaitali kuposa nthaŵi zonse zimene bungwe linkachita.

en: Asylum-seekers, immigrants adjusting their status to permanent residence and other noncitizens going through the U.S. immigration process are among the noncitizens affected by the latest work authorization extension.
ny: Anthu ofuna kuthawira ku United States, anthu amene akupita kukachita ntchito zina zosaloledwa ndi boma la United States, komanso anthu ena amene akupita kukachita ntchito zina zosaloledwa ndi boma la United States, ndi ena mwa anthu amene akukhudzidwa ndi lamulo la posachedwapa loti anthu azigwira ntchito.

en: The agency had reported that processing times for asylum applicants looking to renew work permits increased from seven months in 2017 to 11 months in 2021.
ny: Bungweli linati nthawi yochitira zinthu anthu ofuna kuthawa kwawo omwe akufuna kuti apitirize ntchito yawo yaufulu inachulukadi kuchokera pa miyezi 7 mu 2017 kufika pa miyezi 11 mu 2021.

en: In March, USCIS announced a program to reduce backlogs, including the expansion of premium processing for certain applications where applicants could pay a higher fee to expedite paperwork processing.
ny: Mu March, USCIS inalengeza pulogalamu yochepetsa kusowa kwa ntchito, kuphatikizapo kuwonjezera ntchito yolemba ntchito ya malipiro a ntchito zina pamene ofuna ntchitoyo akanatha kulipira ndalama zambiri kuti ntchito ya mapepala ifulumizidwe.

en: According to the USCIS, most of the announced changes simply restore options offered before the Trump administration's slowdown of USCIS processing and before the COVID-19 pandemic further slowed the agency's resources.
ny: Malinga ndi USCIS, kusintha kwakukulu komwe kulengezedwa kumangobwezeretsa zosankha zomwe zinaperekedwa boma la Trump lisanachepetse kukonza USCIS komanso mliri wa COVID-19 usanachepetse chuma cha bungwe.

en: "For several years, USCIS has been in a precarious financial situation that has impaired the efficient completion of caseloads. The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated these challenges in 2020, in addition to a hiring freeze and furlough threat leading to workforce attrition and severely reduced capacity. In 2021, before USCIS could recover from these fiscal and operational impacts, there was a sudden and dramatic increase in EAD (Employment Authorization Document) initial and renewal filings," according to the USCIS statement.
ny: "Kwa zaka zingapo, USCIS yakhala ili m'malo azachuma omwe adasokoneza kukwaniritsidwa kwa milandu. Mliri wa COVID-19 udakulitsa zovuta izi mu 2020, kuphatikiza pa kuundana kwa ntchito ndi chiwopsezo cha chilolezo chomwe chidatengera kuchepa kwa ogwira ntchito komanso kuchepa kwakukulu kwa mphamvu. Mu 2021, USCIS isanathe kuchira pazokhudza ndalamazi komanso magwiridwe antchito, panali kuwonjezeka kwadzidzidzi komanso kwakukulu kwa ma EAD (Employment Authorization Document) oyamba ndi kukonzanso, " malinga ndi mawu a USCIS.

en: The USCIS historically has been underfunded because most of the agency's funding comes from application fees that have stalled at $5 billion a year since 2019.
ny: USCIS yakhala ikuchepa chifukwa ndalama zambiri zomwe bungweli limapereka zimachokera ku ndalama zofunsira ntchito zomwe zakhala zisanathe pa $ 5 biliyoni pachaka kuyambira 2019.

en: What Is the US-Launched 'Uniting for Ukraine' Program?
ny: Kodi Pulogalamu ya 'Kugwirizana kwa Ukraine' Yotulutsidwa ndi United States N'chiyani?

en: U.S. President Joe Biden recently announced the Uniting for Ukraine program, which aims to streamline the process for Ukrainians who have fled their country and are seeking safety in the United States.
ny: Purezidenti wa United States, Joe Biden, posachedwapa walengeza za pulogalamu ya Uniting for Ukraine, yomwe cholinga chake ndi kuchepetsa njira zothandizira anthu aku Ukraine omwe athawa m'dziko lawo ndipo akufuna chitetezo ku United States.

en: The new program, which took effect Monday, will complement existing legal pathways available to those fleeing Russian aggression due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine crisis, Biden administration officials said.
ny: Pulogalamu yatsopanoyi, yomwe idayamba kugwira ntchito Lolemba, idzawonjezera njira zalamulo zomwe zilipo kwa iwo omwe akuthawa chiwawa cha Russia chifukwa cha mavuto aku Russia-Ukraine, akuluakulu a boma la Biden adati.

en: "The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) will continue to provide relief to the Ukrainian people, while supporting our European allies who have shouldered so much as the result of Russia's brutal invasion of Ukraine," Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas said in a statement to reporters on April 21.
ny: "Department of Homeland Security (DHS) ya ku United States ipitiliza kupereka chithandizo kwa anthu a ku Ukraine, pamene ikuchirikiza ogwirizana athu a ku Ulaya omwe avutika kwambiri chifukwa cha kuphulika kwachiwawa kwa Russia ku Ukraine", adatero Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas m'mawu kwa atolankhani pa April 21.

en: What is Uniting for Ukraine?
ny: Kodi Kuphatikiza Ukraine N'kutani?

en: The program allows U.S. citizens and residents to sponsor Ukrainian refugees under different immigration statuses. The online portal, open to potential sponsors or organizations, is accepting applications and has received more than 4,000 requests so far, CNN reported.
ny: Pulogalamuyi imalola nzika za US ndi okhala kuti athandizire othawa kwawo aku Ukraine malinga ndi zigawo zosiyanasiyana za anthu osamukira.

en: Who qualifies under the program?  Ukrainians, or an immediate family member of a Ukrainian citizen. They must have a U.S. sponsor and have been a resident of Ukraine as of February 11.
ny: Kodi ndi ndani amene ali m'gulu la anthu amene ali m'dzikoli? A Ukraine, kapena achibale a nzika ya ku Ukraine.

en: What are the requirements?   They must pass security checks — including a fingerprint and an FBI name check and biographic and biometric screening — and meet public health requirements, such as having the proper vaccinations, before entering the U.S.
ny: Kodi zofunika ndi ziti? Ayenera kudutsa kuwunika kwa chitetezo  kuphatikizapo kuwunika kwa zala ndi dzina la FBI ndi kufufuza kwa biographic ndi biometric  ndikukwaniritsa zofunikira zaumoyo wa anthu, monga kukhala ndi katemera woyenera, asanapite ku US

en: Those approved will be allowed to travel to the U.S., be considered for humanitarian parole on a case-by-case basis, stay in the country for two years, and apply for work permits.
ny: Anthu amene avomerezedwa adzaloledwa kupita ku United States, kuzengedwa mlandu kuti apatsidwe chilolezo cha anthu kuti apite kwawo, kukhala m'dzikolo kwa zaka ziwiri, ndi kupempha chilolezo chogwira ntchito.

en: "The United States strongly encourages Ukrainians seeking refuge in the United States who do not have and are not eligible for a visa to seek entry via Uniting for Ukraine from Europe. This will be the safest and most efficient way to pursue temporary refuge in the United States," a DHS statement said.
ny: "United States ikulimbikitsa kwambiri anthu a ku Ukraine ofuna kuthawira ku United States omwe alibe visa kuti alowe ku Ulaya kudzera ku Uniting for Ukraine. Iyi idzakhala njira yotetezeka komanso yothandiza kwambiri yopezera chitetezo kwakanthawi ku United States", inatero mawu a DHS.

en: Who qualifies as a sponsor?
ny: Kodi ndani amene ali woyang'anira?

en: U.S. citizens and other residents who hold lawful status in the United States or who are beneficiaries of Deferred Enforced Departure, Temporary Protected Status, or Deferred Action, among others.
ny: Nzika za ku United States ndi anthu ena okhala m'dzikoli omwe ali ndi udindo wovomerezeka ku United States kapena omwe amapindula ndi Deferred Forced Departure, Temporary Protected Status, kapena Deferred Action, pakati pa ena.

en: Sponsors will be required to prove they can financially support the refugee while they are in the U.S. They also need to pass security and background vetting "to protect against exploitation and abuse." The Ukrainian applicant will receive authorization only after everything is verified, including that the sponsor has the means to support them while they are in the U.S.
ny: Opereka chithandizo adzafunika kutsimikizira kuti angathe kuthandiza munthu wothawa kwawoyo ali ku US. Ayenera kupitanso ku chitetezo ndi kufufuza "kuti ateteze ku kugwiriridwa ndi kuzunzidwa". Wofunsira ku Ukraine adzalandira chilolezo pokhapokha chilichonse chatsimikiziridwa, kuphatikizapo kuti wothandizira ali ndi njira zowathandizira pamene ali ku US

en: Who is not eligible for parole under the program?
ny: Kodi ndani amene sangakhale ndi ufulu wosaloledwa kukhululukidwa pa nthawi imene ali pa udindo?

en: Ukrainian citizens already in the U.S. are not eligible for parole under Uniting for Ukraine.
ny: Anthu a ku Ukraine amene ali kale ku US sakhala ndi ufulu wochita zinthu pa nthawi imene akukhala pa ufulu wochita zinthu mogwirizana ndi mgwirizano wa Ukraine.

en: However, they can apply for Temporary Protected Status, which is another form of humanitarian relief that allows people to legally stay and work in the U.S.
ny: Komabe, iwo angathe kulembetsa kuti apeze Chitetezo Chachikhalire, chomwe ndi mtundu wina wa chithandizo cha anthu chimene chimalola anthu kukhala ndi kugwira ntchito mwalamulo ku US

en: What about those arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border?
ny: Nanga bwanji anthu amene amafika pa malire a United States ndi Mexico?

en: Citing safety issues, U.S. officials have urged Ukrainians not to travel to Mexico in hopes of entering the United States. In addition, U.S. Customs and Border Protection has no place to hold them while they go through the Uniting for Ukraine vetting process.
ny: Pofotokoza za chitetezo, akuluakulu a ku United States apempha anthu a ku Ukraine kuti asayende ku Mexico n'cholinga choti alowe ku United States. Kuwonjezera apo, boma la United States Customs and Border Protection lilibe malo oti liziwasunga pamene akupita ku United for Ukraine.

en: Since Uniting for Ukraine's launch on Monday, Ukrainians who arrive at U.S. ports of entry without a valid visa or without preauthorization to travel to the United States through the Uniting for Ukraine program will be denied entry and told to apply to the program.
ny: Kuyambira Lolemba, a Ukraine omwe amafika ku US popanda visa yovomerezeka kapena chilolezo chopita ku United States kudzera mu pulogalamu ya Uniting for Ukraine, adzakanidwa kulowa ndipo adzauzidwa kuti azifunsira pulogalamuyi.

en: Biden officials hope this will curb the number of Ukrainian migrants seeking humanitarian parole along the border.
ny: Akuluakulu a Biden akuyembekeza kuti izi zidzachepetsa chiwerengero cha othawa kwawo aku Ukraine omwe akufunafuna chithandizo cha anthu pa malire.

en: Those at the border must apply under the rules of Uniting for Ukraine, meaning they must have a qualifying sponsor or a non-government agency willing to sponsor them in the U.S. for up to two years. And they need to have all required vaccinations and pass background checks.
ny: Anthu omwe ali kumalire ayenera kulembetsa malinga ndi malamulo a Uniting for Ukraine, kutanthauza kuti ayenera kukhala ndi wothandizira woyenerera kapena bungwe la non-government lomwe likufuna kuwathandizira ku US kwa zaka ziwiri. Ndipo ayenera kukhala ndi katemera onse oyenera ndikudutsa zowunikira.

en: The Biden administration announced the private sponsorship initiative as another way the U.S. hopes to achieve President Biden's commitment to welcome up to 100,000 Ukrainians displaced by the Russian military invasion.
ny: Boma la Biden linalengeza za njira yothandizira anthu payekha monga njira ina yomwe US ikuyembekeza kukwaniritsa kudzipereka kwa Purezidenti Biden kulandira anthu 100,000 aku Ukraine omwe asamuka chifukwa cha nkhondo ya asilikali ya Russia.

en: As of Thursday, almost 5.4 million refugees have since left Ukraine, according to U.N. data.
ny: Malinga ndi zimene bungwe la United Nations linanena, mpaka Lachinayi, anthu pafupifupi 5.4 miliyoni achoka ku Ukraine.

en: Report: Rwanda Should Ease Restrictions On 2003 National Elections - 2001-10-15
ny: Lipoti: Rwanda Iyenera Kuchepetsa Kuletsa Kusankhidwa kwa National Elections - 2001-10-15

en: In 2003 Rwanda will hold its first national elections since the 1994 genocide. A new report says the government of Rwanda needs to relax its control over public life if the polls are to have any credibility.
ny: Mu 2003, dziko la Rwanda lidzachita chisankho choyamba cha dziko lonse kuyambira pamene panachitika kupha anthu ambiri mu 1994. Lipoti latsopano linanena kuti boma la Rwanda liyenera kuchepetsa kulamulira moyo wa anthu ngati likufuna kuti mavoti akhale odalirika.

en: There was relief when the Rwandan Patriotic Front seized power in Rwanda in 1994, ending the genocide in which about 800,000 minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus were killed.
ny: Panali mpumulo pamene Front Patriotic Rwanda inalanda ulamuliro ku Rwanda mu 1994, kuthetsa kupha anthu pafupifupi 800,000 a mtundu wa Tutsi ndi Ahutu.

en: The new military government promised to restore democracy to Rwanda via elections in 2003.
ny: Boma latsopano la asilikali linalonjeza kubwezeretsa demokalase ku Rwanda kudzera m'masankho a 2003.

en: That process began in March this year, with district elections.
ny: Ntchito imeneyi inayamba mu March chaka chino, ndi chisankho cha zigawo.

en: Senior analyst Francois Grignon, of the International Crisis Group, a Brussels-based policy research organization, says he was disappointed with the district poll. Mr. Grignon says the process was so tightly controlled that he maintains no genuine opposition candidates were allowed to stand.
ny: Katswiri wamkulu wa kafukufuku wa m'madera a ku Brussels, Francois Grignon, wa bungwe la International Crisis Group, ananena kuti anakhumudwa ndi kafukufuku wa m'madera a m'maderawo.

en: "There was a screening and there was a preparation of the elections, which did not allow other candidates than those who had been rubber-stamped by the government to actually contest, especially for the executive positions within the local authorities," he says. "If consensual democracy means that the political debate is actually handled before the electoral contest in such a way that it does not lead to a real competition then there is no democracy at all."
ny: "Panali kuonerera ndi kukonzekera chisankho, zomwe sizinalole ofuna ena kupatulapo amene boma linawapatsa chisindikizo cha mphira kuti ayambe kupikisana, makamaka pa maudindo akuluakulu m'boma la m'deralo", akutero. "Ngati demokalase yogwirizana ikutanthauza kuti mkangano wa ndale umayendetsedwa mpikisano wa chisankho usanachitike m'njira yoti usapereke mpikisano weniweni ndiye kuti palibe demokalase konse".

en: In a new report, titled Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, the International Crisis Group urges the international community to pressure Rwanda's government to liberalize political activity.
ny: M' lipoti latsopano lotchedwa Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, International Crisis Group ikulimbikitsa gulu la mayiko padziko lonse kuti lifulumizitse boma la Rwanda kuti lizichita zinthu zandale.

en: The report notes that the military dominates public life and there is little open criticism of the government, either in the media or by opposition figures. The Rwanda government argues that allowing a range of opinions would be dangerous in a country struggling to come to terms with its bloody past.
ny: Lipotilo limanena kuti asilikali akulamulira moyo wa anthu ndipo palibe amene akudzudzula boma mosapita m'mbali, kaya ndi atolankhani kapena anthu otsutsa.

en: But Mr. Grignon says dissent is simply being driven underground or outside Rwanda's borders.
ny: Koma Bambo Grignon amanena kuti anthu amene sakugwirizana ndi zimene amakhulupirira akuyendetsedwa mobisa kapena kunja kwa malire a Rwanda.

en: "Opponents to the regime have to flee the country or to join in rebel movements outside the country or in the Congo and no chance to express a different view," he says. "All the good policies that the government has been implementing - including the organization of the elections, national elections, presidential and parliamentary, in 2003 - will lack the credibility because they were not implemented in an environment that actually allowed a fair contest to take place," he says.
ny: Iye anati: "Anthu otsutsa bomali ayenera kuthawa m'dzikoli kapena kulowa m'magulu a zigawenga kunja kwa dziko kapena ku Congo ndipo alibe mwayi wofotokoza maganizo awo mosiyana ndi amenewa. Ndondomeko zonse zabwino zimene boma lakhala likugwiritsa ntchito - kuphatikizapo kukonza zisankho, zisankho za dziko, zoyang'anira boma ndi za parliamentary, mu 2003 - sizidzakhala zodalirika chifukwa sizinayendetsedwe m'malo amene angalole kuti mpikisano wabwino uchitike", akutero.

en: Mr. Grignon says greater freedom of expression would strengthen Rwanda's reconciliation process and enhance its chances of a peaceful future.
ny: A Grignon akuti ufulu waukulu wa kulankhula ungalimbikitse njira ya chiyanjanitso cha Rwanda ndi kuonjezera mwayi wake wa tsogolo lamtendere.

en: He says the international community's involvement in reconstruction projects gives it the leverage to make this plain to the Rwandan government.
ny: Iye akuti kuloŵerera kwa gulu la mayiko m'mapulojekiti omanga kumapatsa mphamvu zowonetsera zimenezi kwa boma la Rwanda.

en: Rwanda Welcomes the Arrest of Former Rebel Leader
ny: Rwanda Yakondwera Ndi Kumangidwa kwa Mtsogoleri Wakale wa Oukirawo

en: Rwandas Justice Minister said his government is pleased with the arrest Monday of a former rebel leader accused of masterminding genocide and violating human rights against Rwandans and Congolese villagers in 1994.
ny: Nduna ya Zachilungamo ku Rwanda yanena kuti boma lake likukondwera ndi kumangidwa Lolemba kwa mtsogoleri wakale wa zigawenga yemwe akuimbidwa mlandu woyambitsa kupha anthu ambiri komanso kuphwanya ufulu wa anthu ku Rwanda ndi kumidzi ya ku Congo mu 1994.

en: French authorities arrested Callixte Mbarushimana, a former leader of the infamous Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR), an ethnic Hutu rebel group.
ny: Akuluakulu a ku France anamanga Callixte Mbarushimana, mtsogoleri wakale wa gulu lotchuka la Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR), gulu la zigawenga la mtundu wa Ahutu.

en: Tharcisse Karugarama welcomed the decision of French authorities to enforce the international arrest warrant issued by his government and the International Criminal Court (ICC) against the former rebel leader.
ny: Tharcisse Karugarama analandira bwino chigamulo cha akuluakulu a boma la France chokhazikitsa lamulo la kumangidwa kwa mtsogoleri wakale wa zigawenga amene boma lake ndi Khoti Loona za Ufulu wa Anthu Padziko Lonse (ICC) linapereka.

en: "It is good news that Callixte Mbarushimana has been (arrested) by the French judicial authority. Good news in the sense that, first, there was an international arrest warrant against him issued by the Rwandan government in respect of (the alleged) act of genocide committed in Rwanda in 1994."
ny: "Ndi nkhani yabwino kuti Callixte Mbarushimana (wamangidwa) ndi akuluakulu a ku France. Nkhani yabwino ndikuti, choyamba, panali lamulo la kumangidwa kwa dziko lonse motsutsana naye lochokera ku boma la Rwanda pokhudzana ndi (zoti) kupha anthu ku Rwanda mu 1994".

en: Karugarama said the Hague-based court sought the arrest of the former rebel leader who was believed to be hiding in France.
ny: Karugarama anati khoti la ku Hague linafuna kumanga mtsogoleri wakale wa zigawenga amene amakhulupirira kuti akubisala ku France.

en: Genocide memorial in Rwanda
ny: Chikumbutso cha Chiwawa cha Anthu ku Rwanda

en: "The International Criminal Court (ICC) conducted its own investigation about his other activities and they found sufficient evidence to support the charge of war crimes and crimes against humanity perpetrated in the DRC and they issued an arrest warrant, which the French judicial authorities have executed."
ny: "Khothi la International Criminal Court (ICC) linayendera nkhani zake zina ndipo linapeza umboni wokwanira wotsimikizira mlandu wa upandu wa nkhondo ndi upandu woukira anthu womwe unachitidwa ku DRC ndipo linapereka chikalata cholamula kuti amangidwe, chomwe akuluakulu a boma la France anakhazikitsa".

en: The Hague-based court accused Mbarushimana and other rebels in the FDLR of using violence against unarmed civilians as their main tool in a campaign to forcefully obtain political power for the rebel group.
ny: Khoti la ku Haag linagamula kuti Mbarushimana ndi zigawenga zina za FDLR akugwiritsa ntchito chiwawa kwa anthu osavala zida monga chida chawo chachikulu pochita kampeni pofuna kukakamiza zigawengazo kuti zipeze mphamvu zandale.

en: According to the ICC, "as a result of this deadly blackmail (by the FDLR rebels), victims were killed, raped, and forcibly displaced, and entire villages were razed to the ground."
